docs.lead_paragraph: In a marathon session, the Senate Finance Committee voted to ease penalties for those without health insurance.

headline.main: Panel Finishes Work on Health Bill Amendments
headline.print_headline: Finance Panel Wraps Up Its Work on Health Care Bill

docs.snippet: In a marathon session, the Senate Finance Committee voted to ease penalties for those without health insurance.

byline.original: By ROBERT PEAR and DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

docs.lead_paragraph: The sound you heard on Thursday night? A collective sigh of relief from many consumers, as the Senate Finance Committee scaled back penalties to be assessed against those who do not buy health insurance. ''The obligation should be first and foremost on the United States government to ensure that these plans will be affordable,'' said Senator Olympia J. Snowe, Republican of Maine.
docs.abstract: Senate Finance Committee has scaled back penalties against those who do not buy health insurance; Sen Olympia J Snow says that US government should make sure that plans are affordable; many readers of New York Times's online forum agree with her and say that legislation will not do enough to hold insurers accountable; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Democrats in Congress and at the White House were abuzz Friday afternoon after Time magazine's Web site published an interview with the former Senate majority leader Bill Frist, Republican of Tennessee, saying he would vote in favor of the Democrats' health care legislation if he were still in Congress. ''I would end up voting for it,'' Mr. Frist, right, said in the interview, with Karen Tumulty. ''As leader, I would take heat for it.''
docs.abstract: Time magazine's Web site publishes interview with former Senate majority leader Bill Frist, saying he would vote in favor of Democrats' health care legislation if he were still in Congress; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Things were looking good for Carol Barbee this fall: she was an executive producer on two new prime-time series. But the first was ''The Beautiful Life,'' so she earned the more unusual distinction of having one of her shows canceled before the other even got on the air. She's left with ''Three Rivers,'' a medical drama that she created that begins on Sunday night on CBS. Its vital signs aren't exactly positive either: the pilot was largely reshot (Joaquim de Almeida out, Alfre Woodard in), and then the revised pilot was swapped with what was scheduled to be the second episode.

headline.main: A Series About Life That Starts With Death

docs.abstract: Mike Hale reviews premiere of new CBS series Three Rivers, starring Alex O'Loughlin and Katherine Moennig; photo (M)
docs.snippet: CBS’s unimaginative “Three Rivers,” which centers on an organ transplant team, is situated stylistically about halfway between “Grey’s Anatomy” and a police procedural.

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the Republican leader, on Friday refused to respond to newly disclosed details of Senator John Ensign's efforts to establish a top aide in a lobbying business following the senator's admitted affair with the man's wife.

headline.main: Senate Republican Leader Silent on Ensign

docs.lead_paragraph: Monologue | Aired Thursday night on NBC: According to a new study out of the University of Michigan, during this bad economy, people's health is actually better than it was before. Isn't that amazing? When times are bad economically, people stay in better health, to which former President Bush said, "You're welcome!"
